keyTakeAways: New Delhi’s air quality reached a hazardous level of 442 on Tuesday morning due to fireworks during Diwali.
PM2.5 levels in New Delhi exceeded the WHO annual guideline by over 59 times, indicating extreme health risks.
The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) rated the air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350.
Despite a Supreme Court ruling allowing only three hours of 'green crackers' use per week, fireworks were set off outside these times.
India’s winter smog is exacerbated by cold, stagnant air trapping pollution from traffic, industry, agriculture, and fireworks.
Lahore, Pakistan, had an AQI of 234, the second-highest globally, due to pollution from Indian Punjab and agricultural fires.
Punjab’s Environment Protection Agency acknowledged that air pollution from Indian Punjab is impacting Pakistani Punjab.
The Ministry of Earth Sciences predicts air quality will remain 'Very Poor to Poor' for days due to ongoing pollution sources.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the Diwali festival in October 2025, New Delhi experienced a severe air quality crisis, with its AQI reaching 442—making it the world’s most hazardous city—due to widespread fireworks and ongoing pollution from traffic, industry, and agriculture. PM2.5 levels were over 59 times higher than the WHO’s annual safe limit, and despite a Supreme Court relaxation permitting limited use of 'green crackers,' fireworks were set off beyond allowed times. The Central Pollution Control Board classified the air as 'very poor,' and the Ministry of Earth Sciences forecast poor air quality to persist. The situation is worsened by cold winter conditions that trap pollutants, and pollution from Indian Punjab is also affecting Lahore, Pakistan, highlighting regional environmental challenges and cross-border health risks.
title: Diwali provokes ‘hazardous’ alert over New Delhi air quality
